WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 307 November 1978 THE IMPORTANCE OF RISK IN AGRICULTURAL PLANNING MODELS Agricultural production, particularly in developing countries, is generally a risky process, and considerable evidence exists to suggest that farmers behave in risk averse ways. Yet risk considerations are rarely incorporated into regional or sector planning models; rather farmers are assumed to behave in a risk-neutral profit maximizing way. Explicit representations of uncertain outcomes and farmers' attitudes toward them have appeared mostly in farm level models. At the aggregate level, more indirect approaches have been used which amount to specifying "conservative" reactions to changes in the light of uncertainty, e.g. the flexibility constraints of recursive programming. On theoretical grounds, neglect of risk averse behavior in agricultural planning models can be expected to lead to important over-statements of the output levels of risky enterprises (often reflected in overly specialized cropping patterns), hence also to overestimates of the value of important resources (e.g. land and irrigation water). This paper reports results from two case studies in Mexico designed to measure the magnitudes of some of these biases and, in the process, provides a quantification of risk aversion at aggregate farm levels. Introduction Agricultural production, particularly in developing countries, is generally a risky process, and considerable evidence exists to suggest that farmers behave in risk averse ways.-/ Yet risk considerations are rarely incorporated into regional or sector planning models; rather farmers are assumed to behave in a risk-neutral profit maximizing way. Explicit representations of uncertain outcomes and farmers' attitudes toward them have appeared mostly in farm level models.. At the aggregate level, more indirect approaches have been used which amount to specifying "conservative" reactions to changes in the light of uncertainty, e.g. the flexibility constraints of recursive programming [Day, 1963]. On theoretical grounds, neglect of risk averse behavior in agricultural planning models can be expected to lead to important over- statements of the output levels of risky enterprises (often reflected in overly specialized cropping patterns), hence also to overestimates of the value of important resources (e.g. land and irrigation water). This paper reports results from two case studies in Mexico designed to measure the magnitudes of some of these biases and, in the process,attempts to provide a quantification of risk aversion at aggregate farm levels. The two models used in this paper are both regional linear programming models of the production of annual crops grown under irrigated lf See, in particular, the following case studies: Cancian [1972], Dillion and Anderson [1971], Francisco and Anderson r19721, Lin, Dean and Moore 11974], Officer and Halter [1968], and O'Mara [19711.
 2. conditions. They are static equilibrium models, and through incorpora- tion of linear demand functions, simulate competitive market equilibria in which both prices and quantities are endogenous. In this respect, their structures are identical to CHAC [Duloy and Norton, 1973] but risk averse behavior is also incorporated through the methodology described in the 1974 article of Hazell and Scandizzo. In section 2 we briefly review the risk specification of the models, and show why ignoring risk averse behavior in programming models can lead to biases in estimated crop outputs and the values of scarce resources. In section 3 we present the two models in some detail, and discuss the methods used to estimate key risk parameters. Section 4 contains the results from the two models, and demonstrates the numerical importance of incorporating risk averse behavior into agricultural planning models. Finally, section 5 contains our brief conclusions. 2. Method of Incorporating Risk The underlying behavioral assumption in our models is that farmers maximize expected net income less its standard deviation -- an (E, a) utility function -- rather than expected profits. This assumption follows a tradition begun by Markowitz [1959] and Tobin [1958] regarding choice under uncertainty. More precisely, however, our assumption is a variation on the approach of Baumol [1963] who used an (E, *a) formulation which gives more reasonable answers than the straight (E, a) approach in some cases. With Baumol's approach, the decision-maker is assumed to subjectively establish a confidence limit and a floor on expected returns, to which the
 3. limit is applied. In this^paper, parametric programming techniques are used to derive values of the subjective parameter . It is well known that a pure (E, a) function, taken over a significant range of values, has some rather strange behavioral properties, and even the assumption of normally distributed outcomes won't rescue it from that fact. Nevertheless, it has been shown that over a limited range of values such a function can be viewed as an approximation, via truncated Taylor's series, to a polynomial function with all the desirable properties. More precisely, the first two terms of a Taylor's series yield an (E, V) utility function, and the (E, a) efficiency frontier is a tangency to it at the equilibrium point. Tsiang 11972, 1974] has provided a careful defense of the (E, a) approach as a useful approximation in certain classes of choice situation, and it has proven to be helpful in improving predictions of behavior under risk at the farm level. Building on that, the purpose of this paper is to show one way in which it may be utilized in an aggregate rather than a micro model. One of Tsiang's conditions for (E, a) analysis to be useful is that the risk be "small" relative to the total wealth of the risk taker. while this conditions may be met for the commercial, irrigated farms covered in our models, it should be noted that it may not be satisfied for the case of rainfed, subsistance farmers confronted with new technologies. Given the underlying (E, fa) behavioral specification, the objective function of an aggregate linear programming model which simulates competitive market equilibria can be written as:

These selected districts are not contiguous, but are scattered throughout the arid agricultural areas of Mexico; they are among the largest districts. Estimation of Risk Parameters In order to incorporate risk averse behavior into the models in accordance with equation (1) , it is necessary to have estimates of Q and n for each irrigation district. In principle D and 2 should be suitable weighted averages of the risk aversion parameters and revenue covariance matrices of individual farms. Such information is not, of course, available, and even if it were, suitable aggregation procedures have not yet been developed. Consequently, in formulating the ALPHA and BETA models, more approximate and aggregate procedures were used. Estimation of 2 Matrices The only available data on revenue variations were time series data on prices and yields at the irrigation district level. Using these data, (13 years in the case of the ALPHA model, but only 6 years for the BETA model), covariance matrices of crop revenues were calculated for each district modelled, after detrending the original crop revenues by linear regressions. There are two potential problems with these estimated Q matrices. First, the approptiate Q matrices should be aggregates of the covariance matrices subjectively perceived by farmers at market equilibrium, and these may well differ from observed statistical relationships. The estimated matrices are therefore good to the extent that farmers' perceived values had converged to the observed statistical relationships, and that the time
 18. series data covered an equilibrium period. The latter requirement may not be too unrealistic, in that few crops showed statistically significant or numerically important trends in their cropping areas during the time periods under consideration. Second, the i matrices should be direct aggregates of individual farm covariance matrices, and should not incorporate any covariance relationships that may exist between farms within a district. It predicts unrealistically high levels of production of cotton, tomatoes, cantaloupes, potatoes, watermelons and sorghum, and particularly low prices for groups 2, 3 and 8.  26. B. Effects on Supply Response Behavior Our results have already shown that the introduction of risk averse behavior into the models leads to different levels of production for most crops as compared to assuming risk neutrality. These results are of course estimates of single points on the product supply functions, but they amply demonstrate the biases inherent in ignoring risk averse behavior in aggregate linear programming models. We turn now to an explora- tion of the broader effects of risk averse behavior on both the slope and location of the domestic supply response functions for selected crops. Given that most domestic prices are endogenous to our two models, it is not possible to derive directly the effects of price changes on domestic supplies. Rather, the location of the domestic demand curves must be shifted, and the model allowed to determine the new equilibrium values of both prices and the quantities supplied. Supply response functions derived in this way also allow for price and quantity adjust- ments in all other markets; they are not therefore the partial supply functions described in economic textbooks, but rather must be considered as total supply response relationships. To simplify the presentation, we have selected two commodities from each model -- commodity groups 2 (tomatoes) and 7 (cereals) from the ALPHA model, and sorghum and safflower from the BETA model. In each experiment, the demand curve for the relevant group or commodity was rotated to the right at discrete intervals of 5% each on the quantity axis, while holding all other demand curves at their initial positions. The experiments were repeated for both risk neutrality and the best fitting

The response relationships obtained from the ALPHA model (Figures 1 and 2 ) are all highly elastic; supplies to the domestic market increasing by about the same percentage as the corresponding shifts in demand. Conclusions This paper has demonstrated that: a) reasonable estimates of risk aversion coefficients can be obtained at aggregate levels through programming techniques; b) biases in estimates of stipply response and resource valuation may be quite significant in planning models which ignore risk averse behavior; and c) the descriptive preformance of agricultural planning models can be considerably improved by introducing risk averse behavioral assumption, even when based on the theoretically problematic (E, a) utility function. The additional data requirements for the incorporation of risk are time series observations on prices and yields, by crop, for the relevant producing regions.

doc.repnme: The importance of risk in agricultural planning models
doc.abstracts: Agricultural production, particularly in developing countries, is generally a risky process, and considerable evidence exists to suggest that farmers behave in risk averse ways. Yet risk considerations are rarely incorporated into regional or sector planning models; rather farmers are assumed to behave in a risk-neutral profit maximizing way. Explicit representations of uncertain outcomes and farmers' attitudes toward them have appeared mostly in farm level models. At the aggregate level, more indirect approaches have been used which amount to specifying "conservative" reactions to changes in the light of uncertainty, e.g. the flexibility constraints of recursive programming. On theoretical grounds, neglect of risk averse behavior in agricultural planning models can be expected to lead to important over-statements of the output levels of risky enterprises (often reflected in overly specialized cropping patterns), hence also to overestimates of the value of important resources (e.g. land and irrigation water). This paper reports results from two case studies in Mexico designed to measure the magnitudes of some of these biases and, in the process, provides a quantification of risk aversion at aggregate farm levels.
